content.text: Place a load of mass \(M = 20 \text{g}\) with its centre at the \(5.0 \text{cm}\) mark of the metre ruler
Explain briefly how you make sure that the centre of the load is at the \(5.0 \text{cm}\) mark. You may draw a diagram if it helps your explanation

Place the metre ruler on the pivot. Adjust the position of the metre ruler on the pivot until the metre ruler is as near as possible to being balanced. Check that the position of the centre of the load remains at the \(5.0 \text{cm}\) mark
Record, in Table 1.1, the scale reading \(p\) on the ruler at the position of the pivot
Calculate, and record in Table 1.1:
• The distance \(a\) between the \(5.0 \text{cm}\) mark and the pivot
Use your value of \(p\) and the equation \(a = p - 5.0\)
• The distance \(b\) between the \(50.0 \text{cm}\) mark and the pivot
Use your value of \(p\) and the equation \(b = 50.0 - p\)
Repeat this procedure for values of \(M = 40 \text{g}\), \(60 \text{g}\), \(80 \text{g}\) and \(100 \text{g}\)
For each value of \(M,\) calculate and record in Table 1.1 the value \(\frac {b}{a}.\)
Plot a graph of \(M / g\) (y-axis) against \(\frac {b}{a}\) (x-axis)
Draw the best-fit line
Determine the gradient \(G\) of the graph. Show clearly on the graph how you obtained the necessary information
The mass \(M_{\mathrm{R}}\) of the metre ruler is numerically equal to G
Write down the value of \(M_{\mathrm{R}}\) in this experiment. Include the unit
\(M_{\mathrm{R}} =\)
The determination of \(M_{\mathrm{R}}\) by this method assumes that the centre of mass of the metre ruler is at the \(50.0 \text{cm}\) mark
A student finds that the centre of mass of his metre ruler is at the \(48.7 \text{cm}\) mark
Suggest how he changes the procedure in **(a)**(ii) to allow for this
In this experiment, you will determine the mass \(M_{\mathrm{R}}\) of a metre ruler using a balancing method
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 1.1
Circuit A
Close the switch
Measure, and record in Table 2.1, the potential difference (p.d.) \(V\) across resistor U
Measure, and record in Table 2.1, the current \(I\) in the circuit
Open the switch
Circuit B
Connect a second \(3\Omega\) resistor between terminals P and Q so that it is in parallel with the first \(3\Omega\) resistor, as shown in Fig. 2.2. The rest of the circuit must remain as in Fig. 2.1
Close the switch
Measure, and record in Table 2.1, the potential difference (p.d.) \(V\) across resistor U
Measure, and record in Table 2.1, the current \(I\) in the circuit
Open the switch
Circuit C
Connect a third \(3\Omega\) resistor between terminals P and Q so that it is in parallel with the other \(3\Omega\) resistors, as shown in Fig. 2.3. The rest of the circuit must remain as in Fig. 2.1
Close the switch
Measure, and record in Table 2.1, the potential difference (p.d.) \(V\) across resistor U
Measure, and record in Table 2.1, the current \(I\) in the circuit
Open the switch
Calculate, and record in Table 2.1, the resistance \(R\) of resistor U for each combination of resistors
Use your readings from Table 2.1 and the equation \(R = \frac{V}{I}\)
A student suggests that the values of \(R\) should be the same
State whether your results support this suggestion. Justify your statement by reference to values from your results
statement
justification
Briefly explain one advantage of using a variable resistor for this purpose rather than the procedure carried out in (a), (b) and (c)
Draw the circuit symbol for a variable resistor
A student determines the resistance of resistor U using a variable resistor to control the current in the circuit
Another student suggests that potential difference and current for resistor U are proportional
State how a graph of potential difference against current for resistor U can confirm this suggestion
In this experiment, you will investigate circuits containing different combinations of resistors. Fig. 2.1 shows **circuit A** which has been set up for you
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 2.1
Mark and label a point \(\mathbf{F}\) approximately in the centre of your ray-trace sheet
Draw a \(5\mathrm{cm}\) long line \(\mathbf{FV}\), from point \(\mathbf{F}\), as shown in Fig. 3.1
Draw two lines, \(\mathbf{FG}\) and \(\mathbf{FE}\), each \(9\mathrm{cm}\) long and at \(50^{\circ}\) either side of \(\mathbf{FV}\), as shown in Fig. 3.1
Draw a normal to line \(\mathbf{FG}\), crossing \(\mathbf{FG}\) at a point \(\mathbf{N}\), \(6\mathrm{cm}\) from \(\mathbf{F}\)
Label the lower end of the normal with the letter \(\mathbf{L}\)
Draw a line \(\mathbf{NA}\), as shown in Fig. 3.1, \(8\mathrm{cm}\) long and at an angle \(\theta_{1} = 15^{\circ}\) to \(\mathbf{NG}\)
Place the plane mirrors on lines \(\mathbf{FG}\) and \(\mathbf{FE}\), with their reflecting surfaces facing inwards, as shown in Fig. 3.1
Place two pins, \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\), on line \(\mathbf{NA}\), a suitable distance apart for accurate ray tracing
Label the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\)
View the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) from the direction indicated by the eye in Fig. 3.1

Place two pins, \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\), a suitable distance apart, so that pins \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\), and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\), all appear one behind the other
Label the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\)
• Draw a line joining \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\). Extend this line \(10\mathrm{cm}\) above \(\mathbf{FE}\)
• Label the lower end of this line with the letter \(\mathbf{B}\). Label the upper end with the letter \(\mathbf{R}\)
• Draw a new line \(\mathbf{NA}\), \(8\mathrm{cm}\) long and at an angle \(\theta_2 = 40^\circ\)
• Repeat the steps in \((\mathbf{b})\)
• Draw a line joining the new positions of \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\). Extend this line until it crosses \(\mathbf{BR}\)
• Label the lower end of this line with the letter \(\mathbf{C}\). Label the upper end with the letter \(\mathbf{T}\)
Measure the acute angle \(\alpha\) between lines \(\mathbf{BR}\) and \(\mathbf{CT}\). (An acute angle is less than \(90^{\circ}\).)
A student thinks that there is a relationship between angle \(\alpha\) and the values of angle \(\theta_1\) from (a) and angle \(\theta_2\) from (d)(i)
State what your results suggest that relationship could be. Justify your answer by reference to values from your results
statement
justification
Suggest one precaution to take in this type of experiment to ensure accurate results
Suggest one reason why different students, all doing this experiment carefully, may not obtain identical results
In this experiment, you will investigate the reflection of light by two mirrors
Carry out the following instructions, using the separate ray-trace sheet provided
You may refer to Fig. 3.1 for guidance
A student investigates the rate of cooling of hot water in a container which has a lid
Plan an experiment which will enable him to compare the effect of lids of different thicknesses on the rate of cooling
The apparatus available includes:
· a beaker
· a supply of hot water
· insulating material from which lids can be cut
You are **not** required to do the experiment
In your plan, you should:
· list any additional apparatus needed
· explain briefly how to do the experiment, including the measurements to take so that the rate of cooling can be determined
· state the key variables to keep constant
· draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how to display the readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)
· explain how to use the readings to reach a conclusion
You may draw a diagram if it helps to explain your plan
